batchMetadata.description: SSAE engagements including examinations, reviews, and agreed-upon procedures

questions.question: The three types of attestation engagements are:

options.B: Examination, review, agreed-upon procedures

questions.explanation: Under SSAE, the three types of attestation engagements are: examination (reasonable assurance), review (limited assurance), and agreed-upon procedures (findings reported, no assurance).
questions.tip: Attestation types: Examination, Review, AUP. Different assurance levels.

questions.conceptTested: Level of assurance by engagement type
questions.question: An examination engagement provides:

options.B: Limited assurance

questions.explanation: An examination provides reasonable assurance, expressed as a positive opinion on whether the subject matter is presented in accordance with the criteria. It's similar to an audit of financial statements.
questions.tip: Examination = Reasonable assurance (like audit). Review = Limited. AUP = No assurance.

questions.question: Attestation engagements can be performed on subject matter that is:

options.B: Any subject matter that is capable of evaluation against suitable criteria

questions.explanation: Attestation can cover various subject matter: internal control, compliance, sustainability, prospective information, and other matters—as long as suitable criteria exist for evaluation.
questions.tip: Attestation = Broad. Any subject with suitable criteria can be examined/reviewed.

questions.question: Suitable criteria for attestation must be:

options.B: Relevant, objective, measurable, complete, and available to users

questions.explanation: Suitable criteria must be: relevant to users, objective (free from bias), measurable (allow consistent measurement), complete (not omit relevant factors), and available to users for understanding.
questions.tip: Criteria must be: Relevant, Objective, Measurable, Complete, Available. Remember ROMCA.

questions.question: In an agreed-upon procedures engagement, the practitioner:

options.A: Expresses an opinion on the subject matter
options.B: Reports findings from procedures agreed upon with the specified parties

questions.explanation: In AUP engagements, the practitioner performs specific procedures agreed upon with the engaging party (and potentially other specified parties) and reports the findings without expressing an opinion or assurance.
questions.tip: AUP = Report findings only. No assurance, no opinion. Users draw own conclusions.

questions.question: Under current SSAE standards, an AUP report:

options.A: Must be restricted to specified parties only
options.B: May be general use under certain conditions
options.C: Must be filed with the SEC

questions.explanation: SSAE 19 removed the requirement that AUP reports be restricted to specified parties. Reports may be general use if the practitioner determines parties who might use the report are capable of understanding.
questions.tip: AUP reports: Can be general use under SSAE 19. No longer automatically restricted.

questions.question: The conclusion in an examination report is expressed as:

options.B: A positive opinion that the subject matter is presented in accordance with criteria

questions.explanation: An examination conclusion is expressed positively: 'In our opinion, [subject matter] is presented, in all material respects, in accordance with [criteria].' This is similar to an audit opinion on financial statements.
questions.tip: Examination = Positive opinion ('In our opinion...'). Like audit report format.

questions.question: The conclusion in an attestation review report is expressed as:

options.B: Negative assurance stating the practitioner is not aware of material modifications needed

questions.explanation: A review conclusion uses negative assurance: 'Based on our review, we are not aware of any material modifications that should be made to [subject matter] for it to be in accordance with [criteria].'
questions.tip: Review = Negative assurance ('Not aware of...'). Limited, not reasonable assurance.

questions.question: A financial forecast differs from a projection in that a forecast:

options.B: Reflects expected conditions, while projection reflects hypothetical assumptions

questions.explanation: A forecast reflects expected conditions and courses of action (best estimate). A projection includes one or more hypothetical assumptions ('what-if' scenarios). Both can be examined.
questions.tip: Forecast = Expected results. Projection = Hypothetical/what-if assumptions.

questions.question: Financial projections should generally be restricted to:

options.B: Parties who have a direct relationship with the responsible party

questions.explanation: Projections typically include hypothetical assumptions and are intended for parties who can discuss assumptions directly with the responsible party. Reports on projections are generally restricted use.
questions.tip: Projections = Restricted use. Forecasts = Can be general use.

questions.question: A compliance attestation engagement may involve:

options.B: Examining compliance with specified requirements, laws, or contractual terms

questions.explanation: Compliance attestation can cover compliance with specified requirements such as regulatory requirements, contractual agreements, or grant requirements. The practitioner examines or reviews compliance.
questions.tip: Compliance attestation: Laws, regulations, contracts, grants. Examine or review compliance.

questions.question: A SOC 1 report is designed for:

options.B: User entities and their auditors evaluating controls relevant to financial reporting
options.D: Internal use by the service organization

questions.explanation: SOC 1 reports address controls at a service organization relevant to user entities' internal control over financial reporting. They are used by user entity management and auditors.
questions.tip: SOC 1 = Financial reporting controls. For user entities and their auditors.

questions.question: A SOC 2 report addresses controls related to:

options.B: Security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy

questions.explanation: SOC 2 reports cover the Trust Services Criteria: security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy. They are typically restricted use for management and users with sufficient understanding.
questions.tip: SOC 2 = Trust Services Criteria. Security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, privacy.

questions.question: A SOC Type 2 report differs from Type 1 in that Type 2:

options.B: Includes testing of operating effectiveness over a period

questions.explanation: Type 1 reports on design of controls at a point in time. Type 2 reports on design and operating effectiveness over a specified period (typically 6-12 months).
questions.tip: Type 1 = Design at point. Type 2 = Design + Operating effectiveness over period.

questions.question: A SOC 3 report is distinguished by being:

options.B: A general use report with a seal for marketing purposes

questions.explanation: SOC 3 is a general use report suitable for public distribution. It provides a seal/logo for marketing but doesn't contain detailed control descriptions or test results like SOC 2.
questions.tip: SOC 3 = General use, marketing seal. Less detail than SOC 2.

questions.question: An examination of pro forma financial information evaluates:

options.B: Whether assumptions are reasonable and the presentation shows expected effects of transactions

questions.explanation: Pro forma examinations evaluate whether assumptions provide a reasonable basis for presenting effects of the transaction, the pro forma adjustments are appropriate, and the presentation properly reflects those adjustments.
questions.tip: Pro forma: Reasonable assumptions? Appropriate adjustments? Proper presentation?

questions.question: An examination of MD&A evaluates whether MD&A:

options.B: Presents required elements and is consistent with F/S and underlying records

questions.explanation: MD&A examination evaluates whether required elements are presented, the historical information is accurately derived from records, and there's consistency with F/S. Forward-looking information is evaluated for reasonableness of assumptions.
questions.tip: MD&A examination: Required elements + Consistency with F/S + Reasonable forward-looking assumptions.

questions.question: In a direct engagement, the practitioner:

options.A: Reports on management's assertion about the subject matter
options.B: Measures or evaluates the subject matter directly and reports findings

questions.explanation: In direct engagements, the practitioner directly measures/evaluates the subject matter against criteria. In assertion-based engagements, the practitioner reports on management's written assertion about the subject matter.
questions.tip: Direct = Practitioner evaluates subject matter. Assertion-based = Evaluate management's assertion.

questions.question: The responsible party in an attestation engagement is:

options.B: The party responsible for the subject matter

questions.explanation: The responsible party is responsible for the subject matter or makes assertions about it. This is often management but could be different from the engaging party or intended users.
questions.tip: Responsible party = Owns the subject matter. May or may not be the client engaging the practitioner.

questions.question: For assertion-based examinations, a written assertion is:

options.B: Required to be provided by the responsible party

questions.explanation: In assertion-based examinations, the responsible party provides a written assertion about the subject matter. The practitioner then examines and opines on whether that assertion is fairly stated.
questions.tip: Assertion-based = Written assertion required from responsible party.

questions.question: Examination procedures typically include:

options.B: Inspection, observation, confirmation, analytical procedures, and inquiry

questions.explanation: Examination procedures are similar to audit procedures: inspection, observation, confirmation, recalculation, reperformance, analytical procedures, and inquiry. The mix depends on the subject matter.
questions.tip: Examination procedures = Similar to audit. Full range of evidence-gathering techniques.

questions.question: Review procedures in attestation typically consist of:

options.B: Primarily inquiry and analytical procedures

questions.explanation: Attestation reviews primarily use inquiry and analytical procedures—less extensive than examination procedures. The goal is limited assurance, not reasonable assurance.
questions.tip: Review = Inquiry + Analytics. Limited procedures for limited assurance.

questions.question: In an AUP engagement, the procedures performed are:

options.B: Agreed upon with the engaging party

questions.explanation: AUP procedures are agreed upon with the engaging party (and potentially other specified parties). The practitioner doesn't determine procedures independently—they must be explicitly agreed to.
questions.tip: AUP = Agreed procedures. Not practitioner's choice. Must be specifically agreed.

questions.question: Attestation on sustainability (ESG) information:

options.B: Can be examined or reviewed if suitable criteria exist

questions.explanation: Sustainability/ESG information can be subject to attestation if suitable criteria exist (like GRI standards, SASB, or other frameworks). Examinations provide reasonable assurance, reviews provide limited assurance.
questions.tip: ESG attestation: Growing area. Needs suitable criteria. GRI, SASB, TCFD can be criteria.

questions.question: Independence requirements for attestation engagements:

options.B: Apply to examinations and reviews but not to AUP
options.C: Apply to all three types of attestation engagements
options.D: Only apply if the client is public

questions.explanation: The practitioner must be independent for all attestation engagements—examinations, reviews, and AUP. Independence is a fundamental requirement for the credibility of the practitioner's report.
questions.tip: Independence required for ALL attestation types, including AUP.

questions.question: Materiality in attestation engagements:

options.A: Is always the same as for financial statement audits
options.B: Depends on the nature of the subject matter and users' needs

questions.explanation: Materiality in attestation depends on the nature of the subject matter and what would influence users' decisions. For non-financial subject matter, different factors may be relevant than for F/S audits.
questions.tip: Attestation materiality: Varies by subject matter. Not always dollar-based.

questions.question: Documentation for attestation engagements should include:

options.B: Evidence of procedures performed, evidence obtained, and conclusions reached

questions.explanation: Like audits, attestation documentation should show the procedures performed, evidence obtained, and basis for conclusions. An experienced practitioner should be able to understand what was done.
questions.tip: Attestation documentation: Same concept as audit. Support the report and conclusions.

questions.question: An examination report must include:

options.B: Title, addressee, subject matter identification, criteria, responsibilities, summary of work, opinion, signature, and date

questions.explanation: Examination reports include: title, addressee, identification of subject matter and criteria, respective responsibilities, description of practitioner's work, opinion, signature, and date.
questions.tip: Examination report: Similar structure to audit report. Multiple required elements.

questions.question: A qualified conclusion in an attestation examination is appropriate when:

options.A: The subject matter is completely misstated
options.B: Misstatement or scope limitation is material but not pervasive

questions.explanation: Like audits, qualified conclusions apply when departure from criteria or scope limitations are material but not pervasive. Material and pervasive issues result in adverse or disclaimer respectively.
questions.tip: Attestation modifications: Same framework as audits. Qualified, Adverse, Disclaimer.

questions.question: Engagement quality review is required for attestation engagements when:

options.B: Determined by firm policy based on engagement characteristics

questions.explanation: Firms establish policies for when engagement quality review is required based on engagement characteristics (public interest entities, complex issues, etc.). It's not required for all attestation engagements.
questions.tip: EQR for attestation: Firm policy determines. Consider engagement complexity and public interest.

questions.question: An examination of XBRL-tagged information evaluates:

options.A: Only the accuracy of financial statements
options.B: Whether XBRL data accurately reflects underlying financial information

questions.explanation: XBRL examinations evaluate whether the XBRL data accurately represents the source financial information using appropriate tags. It's about accuracy of tagging, not the underlying F/S accuracy.
questions.tip: XBRL attestation: Tags accurate? Reflects source information properly?

questions.question: Under SSAE 18, a service auditor must:

options.B: Obtain a written assertion from service organization management

questions.explanation: SSAE 18 requires the service auditor to obtain a written assertion from service organization management about the description of controls and (for Type 2) their operating effectiveness.
questions.tip: SSAE 18: Written assertion required from service organization management.

questions.question: In a SOC report using the carve-out method:

options.A: Subservice organizations are included in the scope
options.B: Subservice organizations are excluded from the service organization's description

questions.explanation: Carve-out method excludes subservice organizations from the description and testing—only describing the nature of services. Inclusive method includes subservice organization controls in the scope and testing.
questions.tip: Carve-out = Exclude subservice. Inclusive = Include subservice controls.

questions.question: Complementary user entity controls (CUECs) in a SOC report are:

options.A: Controls tested by the service auditor
options.B: Controls at user entities that are assumed to be in place for service organization controls to operate effectively

questions.explanation: CUECs are controls at user entities that must be in place and operating for the service organization's controls to achieve control objectives. The service auditor identifies these but doesn't test them.
questions.tip: CUECs: User entity must have these for service org controls to work. User auditor tests them.

questions.question: An attestation engagement letter should include:

options.B: Objective, scope, responsibilities, criteria to be used, and expected form of report

questions.explanation: The engagement letter documents: engagement objective, subject matter, criteria to be used, responsibilities of practitioner and responsible party, expected report form, and other relevant matters.
questions.tip: Attestation engagement letter: Similar to audit. Objective, scope, responsibilities, criteria, report form.
